turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Chiba 1st district (1947–93).
turn.2: Chiba 1st district (1947–93) Chiba 1st district was a constituency of the House of Representatives in the Diet of Japan.
turn.3: What was the most important fact about this district?
turn.4: Between 1947 and 1993 it elected initially four, later five Representatives by single non-transferable vote.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: It was located in Chiba and, as of 1993, consisted of the cities of Chiba (w/o the former town of Toke), Funabashi, Yachiyo, Ichihara and Narashino.
turn.7: Are these facts still true today?
turn.8: Today, the area extends into Chiba's 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 9th single-member electoral districts.
turn.9: What has changed in the district?
turn.10: Until the decline of the LDP in the 1970s after the oil crisis and the Lockheed scandal, the relatively urban district was won by a majority of LDP candidates several times.
turn.11: Who were the main players in the district?
turn.12: Representatives for Chiba 1st district included LDP faction leader and home affairs minister Shōjirō Kawashima (Kawashima faction), defense minister Shigejirō Inō (Satō faction), construction minister Ihei Shiseki (Fukuda faction), "sōri-fu" minister Sōichi Usui (Miki faction) and his son Hideo Usui (Miki (→Kōmoto) faction) and, in the final election period before the election reform, opposition politicians Yoshihiko Noda (JNP) and Kazuo Shii (JCP) who later went on to play leading roles in the opposition parties.
